citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The current pest control program of the facility is not meeting USDA requirements to prevent infestation and
contamination of the facility by mice. During facility inspection the following was observed:
1) mouse feces, some intermixed with wall foam insulation particles, along floors and walls in whelping, prep/treatment
and storage areas.
2) mouse feces on counter next to bowls and sink in prep/treatment room
3) mouse feces on refrigerator support shelf in prep/treatment room
4) mouse feces on shelving unit and on food bags in bedding/food storage room
5) 10 dead mice were visually observed on glue traps in the facility
Rodents can carry diseases which may infect and harm other animal species, including dogs. These diseases may be
spread through rodent droppings and urine. An effective pest control program, including control of rodents, must be
established and maintained to prevent pest infestation and contamination, and to ensure the health and well-being of
facility animals.
Correct by April 07, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.11(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The current pest control program of the facility is not meeting USDA requirements to prevent infestation and 
contamination of the facility by mice. During facility inspection the following was observed: 
1) mouse feces, some intermixed with wall foam insulation particles, along floors and walls in whelping, prep/treatment 
and storage areas.  
2) mouse feces on counter next to bowls and sink in prep/treatment room 
3) mouse feces on refrigerator support shelf in prep/treatment room 
4) mouse feces on shelving unit and on food bags in bedding/food storage room 
5) 10 dead mice were visually observed on glue traps in the facility 
 
Rodents can carry diseases which may infect and harm other animal species, including dogs. These diseases may be 
spread through rodent droppings and urine. An effective pest control program, including control of rodents, must be 
established and maintained to prevent pest infestation and contamination, and to ensure the health and well-being of 
facility animals. 
 
Correct by April 07, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
